metadata.title: Critical heat flux and pool boiling heat transfer analysis of synthesized zirconia aqueous nano-fluids

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate / ichmt
Critical heat flux and pool boiling heat transfer analysis of synthesized zirconia aqueous nano-fluids
M.M. Sarafraz ⁎, T. Kiani, F. Hormozi Faculty of Chemical, Petroleum and Gas Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: mohamadmohsensarafraz@gmail.com
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.icheatmasstransfer.2015.12.00 0735-1933/© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Available online 17 December 2015
In this work, experimental investigation on the pool boiling heat transfer to zirconium oxide nano-fluids was carried out. Zirconium oxide was prepared using chemical sol-gel method. Characterization of synthesized nano-particles was performed using scanning electron microscopic, x-ray diffraction and particle size count tests. The obtained nano-powders were then dispersed in water–ethylene glycol mixture 50:50 as a base fluid at volumetric particle concentrations of 0.025%, 0.05%, 0.075%, and 0.1%. Before boiling experiments, thermal conductivity of zirconium oxide was experimentally measured at different weight percentages. Results demonstrated that pool boiling heat transfer coefficient can be enhanced up to 12% at vol. % = 0.1. A very slight particle deposition was also observed on the surface after boiling experiments, which had no impact on heat transfer coefficient, but to enhance the critical heat flux value up to 29%. Surface characterization demonstrated that static contact angle of liquid drop on the surface decreases by forming the thin deposition layer on the surface, which increases the wettability and capillary wicking action as well. Roughness of surface was found to be increased due to the deposition of nano-fluids too.
© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Synthesized zirconium oxide Ethylene glycol Pool boiling Deposition Flat disk surface

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Boiling heat transfer is one of the hot-debated topics and has been regarded as one of the major interests of the heat transfer experts. Due to the complexities encountered in boiling-related studies, still there are many efforts toward the understanding the governing mechanism and exact behavior of coolant in boiling conditions.When boiling comes to the nano-fluids (colloidal suspensions comprising solid particles withmean size of 0–100 nm dispersed in a traditional coolant such as water or ethylene glycol), complications are intensified, since nanofluids can lose their stability and form a deposition layer on the surface due to the evaporation of base fluid. This behavior can change the surface characteristics, which lead the thermal performance of nano-fluid to be changed. Another important influence of nano-fluid deposition can be found on the critical heat flux crisis. Critical heat flux (CHF crisis) in boiling heat transfer, as a definition, is the limited point in which phase change process acts in a way that bubbles can fully cover and overwhelm the heating surface and lead to the overheating problem. In this condition, heat transfer coefficient starts to be deteriorated over the higher given heat fluxes, which can finally damage the surface or explode the heater, since heat cannot be transferred properly from the surface toward the bulk of coolant. A nucleate boiling system is comprised of three main heat transfer mechanisms: (1) heat conduction through liquid from the boiling surface to the liquid–vapor equilibrium
(M.M. Sarafraz).
8
interface, (2) evaporation at the liquid–vapor interface toward the vapor phase, (3) departing the vapor from the heating surface in form of bubble and vapor blanket depending on the applied heat flux. The critical heat flux phenomena occur when either generation or escape of vapor is restricted or hindered. In terms of boiling heat transfer coefficient, there are evidences showing that presence of nanoparticles can enhance the boiling performance [1–7], there are still others who back up the notion that boiling heat transfer can be deteriorated in nano-fluids [8–12]. These controversial opinions are a huge motivation for studying the boiling heat transfer in different conditions and for different nano-fluids to find a general answer. For example, in an experimental work conducted by Fan et al. [13], stainless steel spheres in dilute aqueous graphene oxide, (GO) nano-sheets nano-fluids at various concentrations (by weight) up to 0.1 wt.% were quenched. The experiments were performed for saturated boiling and boiling curves were obtained for the nano-fluids in comparison to the baseline case of purewater. It was shown that quenching is accelerated upon increasing the concentration of nano-fluids. The enhanced boiling heat transfer by the nano-fluids was interpreted in relation to the modified surface properties, including morphology, wettability, and roughness, on the quenched surfaces. Sarafraz et al. [14–16] established experiments on thermal performance of alumina and copper oxide nano-fluids in a boiling pool. They demonstrated that pool boiling heat transfer can be deteriorated over the extended time, since nano-particles can form a fouling layer on the surface, which causes a significant thermal resistance. Tang et al. [17] performed a set of experiments on pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of gamma alumina/R141b nano-fluids on a horizontal
Nomenclatures
H Heat transfer coefficient, kW/m2. K I Current, Amper K Thermal conductivity, W/m. K Lc Capillary characteristic Q Heat flux, kW/m2 R Heater radius, m S Microstructure wall space, m T Temperature, K V Voltage, volt Z Axial distance, m
Greek letters ρ Density, kg/m3 σ Surface tension, N/m θ Contact angle, degree
Abbreviations CHF Critical heat flux DIW Deionized water HF Heat flux HTC Heat transfer coefficient WEG50 Water–ethylene glycol 50:50 mixture
flat square copper surface at heat fluxes ranged from 10 to 200 kW/m2. The surface roughness has been controlled by sandpaper of grade#2000 before boiling. The results show that the presence of alumina nanoparticles can enhance or deteriorate the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, which strongly depends on the concentration of nano-particles dispersed in base fluid. In another study, nucleate boiling heat transfer of alumina–water–ethylene glycol nano-fluids under atmospheric pressure was investigated by Raveshi et al. [18]. He and his co-workers evaluated six different volume fractions of the nano-fluids to study the impact of concentration on boiling heat transfer of binary mixture of water/ethylene glycol based nano-fluids. The results showed the high effectiveness of the nano-particles on heat transfer coefficient. In addition, the experimental results indicated that there is an optimum volume concentration of nano-particles, inwhich the heat transfer coefficient has its maximum value. Furthermore, the optimum volume concentration of nano-particle and themaximum increment of boiling heat transfer coefficient in their study were 0.75% and 64%, respectively. In abovementioned researches, nano-fluids have been supplied by a manufacturer, dispersed in to a base fluid, and stabilized using post chemical treatment such as surfactants, dispersants, or pH control methods. In this work, special attention has been paid to the zirconia and its potential application(s) in thermal systems. For this purpose, synthesized zirconiumoxide is added into thewater–ethylene glycol 50:50,WEG50 for enhancing its thermal features, while zirconia is produced using sol-gel method, and then dispersed into the base fluid without any additives or chemical surfactants. Pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of prepared nano-fluids are then experimentally investigated and compared to tradition WEG50 coolant. Results of this work interestingly show that this nano-fluid not only have wide applications in chemical reactions and catalytic industries but also may be utilized in advanced thermo-fluid and engineering systems as a coolant.

sections.heading: 2.1. Material and nano-fluid preparation
sections.text:
In order to produce the zirconium oxide, (ZrO2) the sol-gel method was implemented. For this purpose, 300 ml of butoxide zirconium as a
precursorwas dissolved in pure ethanol in a cleanflask at room temperature, while themixturewas agitated by a stirrer at speed of 100 rpm. In order to produce the gel, deionized water was then added into themixture and constantly heated at 300 °C. The obtained gel was dried for 24 hours by a microwave-assisted dryer set at 100 °C. As a post treatment, the product was calcined by a furnace with rate of 3 °C/min up to 400 °C for 4 hours. The final product was crushed, grinded, and screened using 60/80 mesh screen. Quality tests were then carried out to ensure about the morphology, size, and quality of zirconium oxide nano-particles. Results of quality tests have been described in Section 2.2. To prepare the nano-fluid, desired mass of ZrO2 was added into the weighted base fluid. For 10 minutes, each nano-fluid was exposed to sonication process using ultrasonic (400 W/20 kHz) to homogenously disperse the nano-particles within the base fluid. Nano-fluids were prepared at weight percentages of 0.025%, 0.05%, 0.075%, and 0.1%. Nano-fluids were prevented from adding any surfactants, since nano-particles have been produced using synthesis technique and surfactant can drastically change the thermo-physical properties of nano-fluids. No sign of settlement or deposition was seen after 1 week of preparation.

sections.heading: 2.2. Quality tests
sections.text: When nano-particles were produced, morphology, size, and purity of themwere precisely determined thanks to the scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and particle size count (PSC) test using digital light scattering instruments. Fig. 1 (a–c) demonstrates the results of quality tests. Fig.1a shows the SEM image taken from the nano-particles. As can be seen, particles are almost spherical, identical in size, and have similar color. Fig.1b represents the XRD pattern belonging to zirconia. As can be seen, peaks of broad due to the nanosized effect. Moreover, no external/unknown peak is detected by XRD, meaning that there is no impurity in the structure of nano-particles. Also, molecular structure (shape phase) of zirconium oxide was found to be cubic. This structure, due to its symmetric bonds, has higher thermal conductivity rather than other molecular structures, which is suitable for heat transfer applications. Fig.1c shows the particle count size test. As can be seen, the dominant particle size is 20–25 nm which is in accordance with SEM image.

sections.heading: 2.3. Experimental setup
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows a schema of the experimental setup used in this work. This test rig consists of four main sections: (1) Discoid copper heater as the test section. (2) Auxiliaries including pre-heater, condenser installed inside the test vessel. (3) Temperature measurement instruments including thermocouples, indicators, data acquisition, and a post-processor computer. (4) Imaging system including a high-speed camera and a digital microscope with magnification of 500× (IPU500×). Nano-fluid is loaded through the inlet port of the test vessel. The vessel is a vertical Pyrex cylinder, which has enough thermal resistance. In the bottom section of stainless steel cap, there is a perforated hole, in which a discoid copper heater is mounted. A small layer of Teflon is used to prevent from any liquid leakage and heat loss between discoid heater and the hole. This discoid heater consists of a dual diameter cylinder with an axial concentric hole at the bottom, in which a 300-Watt bolt heater is inserted to supply the required heat for boiling experiments. The bolt heater power supply is provided by a 0–300 volt AC transformer connected to the urban power supply. Detailed geometrical specifications of discoid heater have been given in Fig. 3. The top surface of discoid heater is fixed horizontally inside the cap, so the surface can be used for pool boiling heat transfer and CHF experiments. The surface is circular with outer diameter of 11 mm. In order to measure the temperature of surface, five calibrated k-type thermocouples with length of 50 mm and diameter of 1 mm (with precision of ±0.1 K) are mounted in the axial holes (with different axial positions) on the
upper section of heater. By installing these thermocouples, temperature gradient can accurately be measured, which precisely extrapolates the boiling surface temperature. For minimizing the thermal resistance of each thermocouple, holes are filled with silicon paste. In terms of heat loss, the circumference of the heater and vessel is heavily isolated by the cylindrical PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene) solid to prevent from any heat losses. By heavily isolating the heater, axial heat transfer toward the surface is guaranteed and no radial heat transfer can be seen in the heater. However, to ensure about radial heat transfer, two k-type thermocouples at (r = −0.5, r = +0.5) was mounted to measure the radial temperature distribution. Results showed that temperature at this two points are the same at any given heat fluxes. Thus, radial heat transfer can be ignored. For measuring the liquid bulk temperature, 4 RTDs (with precision of ±0.1 K) are installed at four different locations of test vessel shown in Fig. 2. The arithmetic average of RTD readings is regarded as the bulk temperature of vessel. Also, to ensure about the saturated boiling, a thermocouple is mounted at the
upper part of the vessel to measure the vapor temperature. A pressure transmitter is also installed to record the pressure inside the vessel. A safety pressure valve is connected to the pressure controller and pressure transmitter to control the pressure of vessel. An auxiliary heater is installed inside the vessel to supply the required heat for preheating of liquid up to saturation temperature. As soon as nano-fluid temperature reaches to the correspondence saturation temperature and pressure, discoid heater is turned on for starting the pool boiling experiments.

sections.heading: 2.4. Data reduction and uncertainty
sections.text:
As mentioned, for calculating the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, it is essential to extrapolate the surface temperature of discoid heater. In fact, the criterion for thermal performance of a nano-fluid is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, which can be calculated using Eq. (1):
h ¼ q Tw−Tb
ð1Þ
In Eq. (1), Tw is the surface temperature, and Tb is the bulk temperature of liquid, q is the applied heat flux to the liquid from the discoid heater, which can be calculated using Eq. (2):
q ¼ −k dT dz
surface
¼ −k T5−T1 Δzaxial
ð2Þ
Z is the axial direction. T1 and T5 are temperatures measured by thermocouples located in position 1 and 5 (see Fig. 3), k is thermal conductivity of copper. Noticeably, according to the Joule's heating effect, heat flux can be directly estimated by Eq. (3) as follows:
q ¼ V : I π:R2
ð3Þ
In this equation, V is voltage (volt); I is electric current of central heater (Amps), and R is the radius of surface of discoid heater. Circumference of discoid heater has been isolated with PTFE, thus one-dimensional conduction heat transfer is the reasonable dominant heat transfer mechanism. Thus, the following linear temperature distribution can be obtained based on Eq. (2):
T ¼ α þ βz ð4Þ
Since at z = 0, T = Tw, therefore, we have
Tw ¼ α; ð5Þ
where α is the intercept of the line fitted on themeasured axial temperatures of discoid heater at a given heat flux. Therefore, alpha can be accurately estimated for each heat flux and is regarded as the surface temperature for each heat flux. Although circumference of discoid heater has been isolated with PTFE, there are possibilities that heat can be lost to the environment. A comparison between the heatfluxes estimated from Eq. (2) and that of calculated by Eq. (3) was made to show the quantity of heat loss alongwith the discoid heater. Fig. 4a shows the results of comparison. Noticeably, thermocouples and multi-meter readings were carried out three times to ensure about reproducibility of data. It can be stated that at lower heat flux, higher uncertainty was seen (for some data more than 6%), while for high heat flux condition, lower uncertainty was registered.
As can be seen in Fig.4a, uncertainty for heat fluxes is lower than 6%, meaning that heat can easily flow from cartridge heater toward the boiling surface and rate of heat loss is reasonable and less than 6%. Fig.4b shows the extrapolation of surface temperature using Eqs (1–5) for heat flux 400 kW/m2. For other heat fluxes, a similar extrapolation methodwas performed. In order to check the uncertainty of experiments, the Kline–McKlintockmethod [19]was used. A detailed uncertainty analysis was performed on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient based on Eqs. (3) and (1) and represented as
Δq q

The maximum calibration error of the thermocouple was 0.1 K. The maximum deviation related to themeasuring of location of the thermocouples was about 0.1%. The measurement error of the power meter (multi-meter and current meter) was 0.5%. Maximum uncertainties of the heat flux and heat loss were also about 9% and less than 6%, respectively. The uncertainty of heat transfer coefficient according to Eq. (6)

equals to 10.1%. Table 1 represents the uncertainty values of instruments used in the present work.

sections.heading: 2.5. Thermal conductivity of nano-fluids
sections.text:
Zirconia is an extremely refractory material with a relatively low thermal conductivity and has wide applications in catalytic industries and chemical reaction based science. However, this material in form of cubic can have reasonable thermal and electrical conductivity coefficient and may have potential application in advanced thermo-fluid science. In order to show the thermal conductivity of zirconia, experimentswere established tomeasure the thermal conductivity coefficient of nano-fluids using KD2 pro instrument. For this purpose, thermal conductivity of nano-fluids was measured at 298 K, 323 K, and 353 K. For better understanding, thermal conductivity enhancement ratio was
implemented as ratio of thermal conductivity of nano-fluid over the base fluid (WEG50). Fig. 5 shows the enhancement ratio parameter as a function of weight percentage (mass concentration) of nano-fluids. As can be seen, thermal conductivity of WEG50 can be enhanced in the presence of ZrO2 nano-particles; however, the rate of enhancement was not anomalous.
Based on the results represented in Fig. 5, it can be confirmed that ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluid can be regarded as potential coolant in heat transfer media, since it has higher thermal conductivity in comparison with the base fluid. Now the main question is: Can this nano-fluid be utilized as a coolant at two-phase condition (e.g. a boiling system)? The following sections try to find an answer for the expressed question.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
In this section, the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of ZrO2/ WEG50 nano-fluids are investigated and results are briefly discussed.
3.1. Enhancement in critical heat flux and pool boiling heat transfer coefficient
Fig. 6a shows the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, (HTC) of ZrO2 / WEG50 nano-fluids at different heat fluxes. As can be seen, heat transfer coefficient is enhanced at higher heat fluxes, which is in accordance with the literature. Interestingly, by increasing themass concentration of ZrO2 nano-particles, heat transfer coefficient of nano-fluid slightly increases such that atmass concentrations of 0.025%, 0.05%, 0.75%, and 0.1%, the average enhancement rates for the heat transfer coefficient are 4.1%, 7.2%, 10.4%, 12.1%, respectively. The reason for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient can refer to the following facts: the first explanation is that the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids is relatively higher than that of the base fluid due to the presence of solid particles, which can improve the thermal conduction mechanism inside the base fluid. Brownian motion is another reason, which can be intensified by bubble formation on the surface. Random mobility of nano-particles can facilitate the heat transfer rate from surface toward the bulk of nano-fluids. Also, as will be shown in next sections, roughness of boiling surface increased due to the deposition of nano-particles. These irregularities can potentially be nucleation sites which improve the bubble formation mechanism. Fig. 6b shows the excess temperature versus heat flux. As can be seen, for ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluids, with increasing the mass concentration of nano-particles, the boiling curve shifts back such that by increasing the mass concentrations, higher excess temperature is registered. However, rate of enhancement in excess temperature is very slight and data points are overlapped at lower heat fluxes. Boiling behavior and HTC trends
obtained by this work are in a good agreement with those of reported by Haris [20], Ding [21], and Prakash [22].
Enhancement in CHF crisis point is another obvious result of this work. Fig. 7 shows the CHF values for ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluids and WEG50 as a base fluid. For the sake of reliability, experiments related to CHF registration were repeated three times. Likewise, a comparison between obtained results and well-known correlations of Zuber [23], Kanlikar [24], Haramura and Katto [25] were carried out. As can be seen, results are in a good agreement with Haramura and Katto correlation.
Experiments showed that a thin layer of ZrO2 nano-particles is formed on the boiling surface which may change the surface characteristics. Therefore, a visualization study was performed on the surface in order to investigate the impact of deposition of zirconia on the CHF enhancement.

sections.heading: 3.2. Surface characterization and CHF enhancement mechanism
sections.text:
For boiling of non-particulate liquids, at higher heat fluxes near the CHF, due to the intensification of bubble coalescence, vapor blanket or mushroom-shaped bubbles are formed. For such bubbles, hotspot regions are easily formed on the surface (all liquids in this region are vaporized and the surface is locally vapor-filled). Subsequently, due to the poor thermal conductivity of vapor, heat cannot be transferred
properly; as a result, CHF crisis occurs. For nano-fluids, due to the porosity of deposition layer and liquid inflows, hotspot regions are fed with absorbed liquid through the porous layer. Therefore, CHF crisis can be delayed. Fig. 8 schematically shows the explanations and mechanism in the porous layer. In Fig. 9, boiling surface can be seen before and after boiling experiments. As can be seen, the fouling layer is porous and a suitable media for capillary wicking action. When a nano-fluid boils, base fluid is evaporated near the surface and a layer of deposition is formed on the surface which can change the surface characteristics. The effective parameter in surface characteristics is surface wettability. Static contact angle is amerit parameter for investigating thewettability of surface. Therefore, contact angle of liquid drop on the surface before and after boiling experiments was measured using IUP-500X digital microscope.
Fig. 10 shows the static contact angle of a liquid drop (with approximate volume of 1 μL) on the surface before and after boiling experiments. As can be seen, due to the deposition layer, contact angle value has been decreased from 86.2° to 59°. This decreasing trend caused the liquid drop to be lying down on the surface and more surfaces are in contact with liquid drop. As mentioned, the deposition layer is porous; therefore, capillary wicking action is expected to be seen in this layer. Subsequently, liquid is absorbed by the porous layer and liquid inflows are created. Thus at lower contact angles, more liquid can be held in porous layer.
Noticeably, according to Eq. (9) [26], contact angle has a strong influence on capillary wicking:
Lc ¼ 2σ cosθRcρg ð9Þ
In Eq. (9), σ is surface tension, ρ is density, g is gravity, Lc is capillary, and θ is contact angle. The best CHF value can be foundwhen the contact angle approaches to zero. At lower contact angles, capillary action drastically increases; therefore,we anticipate that at highermass concentrations, better CHF enhancement can be seen, which is practically in accordance with our obtained results. Park et al. [27] studied the effect of surface wettability of alumina–water nano-fluid and graphene/ graphene oxide nano-fluids and they could not find a definite relation between surface wettability and CHF enhancement. Kim and Kim [28] reported that the capillary wicking on the nano-porous layer delayed the dryout and cooled the dry spot, thus resulting in the enhancement of CHF. Ahn and his co-workers [29] showed that the water absorption phenomenon played a role on the saturated porous layer during nucleate boiling of RGO. However, capillary wicking alone did not
seem adequate to explain the mechanism behind an anomalous increase in CHF around 320%. Although it seems that the explained mechanism can justify the CHF enhancement for ZrO2/WEG50 nanofluid, more studies are still required to identify the exact mechanism for anomalous enhancement of CHF in other nano-fluids.
Fig. 10. Visual static contact angle of liquid drop on bo
Fig. 9. Boiling surface before and after boiling experiments. a) Before experiments. b) After boil 0.075%. e) After boiling of nano-fluid 0.1%.

sections.heading: 3.3. Bubble formation near the CHF crisis
sections.text:
In order to ensure about the suggestedmechanism for CHF enhancement, bubble formation should be visually investigated. Since nanofluids are not transparent, the study just performed on base fluid,
iling surface deposited with ZrO2 nano-particles.
ing of nano-fluid 0.025%. c) After boiling of nano-fluid 0.05%. d) After boiling of nano-fluid
while the bubble formation can be extended to the nano-fluids. Fig. 11 shows the bubble formation of WEG50 on the boiling surface at heat flux ranges from 35 to 1095 kW/m2 (0.98CHF value). As can be seen, at lower heat fluxes, bubbles are discretely formed on the surface, which remains more free heat transfer area, while at heat flux 1095 kW/m2 (near to CHF crisis point) bubbles are coalesced in a mushroom-shaped vapor blanket, which can considerably increase the possibility of CHF crisis.
Note that, underneath of growing bubbles, vapor-filled regions are constituted; these regions have very pool thermal conductivity, which is called hotspot regions. For nano-fluids, there is a different story due to the fouling layer. According to abovementioned mechanism, formation of hotspot regions can be compensated by capillary wicking action through the porous deposition layer. So the suggested mechanism is consistent with boiling behavior of zirconia/WEG50. To draw a conclusion, it can be stated that ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluids can slightly increase the heat transfer coefficient (up to 12.1%) and CHF value (up to 29%) in comparisonwithWEG50. Thus, application of synthesized ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluids in boiling heat transfer systems can be justifiable.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A set of experimentswas carried out on thepool boilingheat transfer characteristics of synthesized zirconia/water–ethylene glycol nanofluids and the following conclusions have been made. Investigation on thermal conductivity demonstrated that zirconia nano-fluid has enough potential for heat transfer applications, because due to the presence of ZrO2 nano-particles, thermal conductivity of WEG50 increased (up to 18% at 353 K).Moreover, ZrO2/WEG50 nano-fluidswere found to slightly enhance the heat transfer coefficient and deposition of nano-particles did not reduce the surface roughness. The enhancement rate for the maximummass concentration (0.1%) was 12.1%. Deposition of zirconia nano-particles on the surface created a porous layer which intensified the capillary wicking action. This phenomenon resulted in enhancement in CHF value because due to the decrease in static contact angle value, more liquid was absorbed by the porous layer and transferred to the hotspot regions underneath the growing bubbles. According to
the visualization study, bubble coalescence phenomenon was found to be intensified at higher heat fluxes, which intensify the CHF crisis as well. All in all, although heat transfer coefficient and CHF enhancement were not anomalous, zirconia/WEG50 may have potential applications in two-phase heat transfer, which requires to be extensively studied.

[27] studied the effect of surface wettability of alumina–water nano-fluid and graphene/ graphene oxide nano-fluids and they could not find a definite relation between surface wettability and CHF enhancement.
Kim and Kim [28] reported that the capillary wicking on the nano-porous layer delayed the dryout and cooled the dry spot, thus resulting in the enhancement of CHF.
Ahn and his co-workers [29] showed that the water absorption phenomenon played a role on the saturated porous layer during nucleate boiling of RGO.

metadata.abstractText: Available online 17 December 2015 In this work, experimental investigation on the pool boiling heat transfer to zirconium oxide nano-fluids was carried out. Zirconium oxide was prepared using chemical sol-gel method. Characterization of synthesized nano-particles was performed using scanning electron microscopic, x-ray diffraction and particle size count tests. The obtained nano-powders were then dispersed in water–ethylene glycol mixture 50:50 as a base fluid at volumetric particle concentrations of 0.025%, 0.05%, 0.075%, and 0.1%. Before boiling experiments, thermal conductivity of zirconium oxide was experimentally measured at different weight percentages. Results demonstrated that pool boiling heat transfer coefficient can be enhanced up to 12% at vol. % = 0.1. A very slight particle deposition was also observed on the surface after boiling experiments, which had no impact on heat transfer coefficient, but to enhance the critical heat flux value up to 29%. Surface characterization demonstrated that static contact angle of liquid drop on the surface decreases by forming the thin deposition layer on the surface, which increases the wettability and capillary wicking action as well. Roughness of surface was found to be increased due to the deposition of nano-fluids too. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
